title: Simon Canuel
text:
Simon Canuel (29 October 1767 – 11 May 1840) was a <a href="List%20of%20French%20generals%20of%20the%20Revolutionary%20and%20Napoleonic%20Wars">French general of the Revolutionary and Napoleonic Wars</a>.
Biography.
Canuel was born in <a href="Les%20Trois-Moutiers">Les Trois-Moutiers</a>, in the <a href="Vienne">Vienne</a>.
French Revolutionary Wars.
He entered military service on January 3, 1787, as a soldier in the , and he earned all his military ranks in the <a href="War%20in%20the%20Vend%C3%A9e">War in the Vendée</a>, as he was promoted by <a href="Jean%20Antoine%20Rossignol">Jean Antoine Rossignol</a> and <a href="Jean-Baptiste%20Kl%C3%A9ber">Jean-Baptiste Kléber</a>, to become a general. He fought along with and during the <a href="battle%20of%20Savenay">battle of Savenay</a>.
In April 1796, general-in-chief, Canuel led the campaign against a counter-revolutionary movement in <a href="Sancerrois">Sancerrois</a>, led by <a href="Antoine%20Le%20Picard%20de%20Ph%C3%A9lippeaux">Antoine Le Picard de Phélippeaux</a>.
First Empire.
<a href="Napoleon%20I">Napoleon I</a> decided not to put Canuel on active service, keeping him in command of various quiet strongholds. Bored at the inaction, he went over to the Bourbons in 1814 and so during the <a href="Hundred%20Days">Hundred Days</a> the following year had to take refuge among the Royalist insurgents of the <a href="Vend%C3%A9e">Vendée</a>.
Later on, he took part in several conflicts including the <a href="Hundred%20Thousand%20Sons%20of%20Saint%20Louis">Hundred Thousand Sons of Saint Louis</a> mission in Spain.
Death.
He died on May 11, 1840 in <a href="Loudun">Loudun</a>.
